item.title: Borderlands 4's 'Dangerous and Sinister' Villain Could Be Just What the Series Needs
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Borderlands 4 introduces a darker, more sinister villain than Handsome Jack, sparking anticipation for the game's release.
  • Borderlands 3 faced criticism for its comedic, non-threatening villains, leading to high hopes for Borderlands 4's antagonist.
  • The potential return to a darker, more menacing adversary in Borderlands 4 could address the shortcomings of its predecessor.

After what has felt like an eternity of waiting, Borderlands 4 has finally been revealed, though only through a cryptic teaser. The teaser hardly reveals anything outright, aside from some Eridian writing and the image of a mysterious face at the end of the trailer, which some fans initially deduced might be Handsome Jack — the main antagonist from Borderlands 2 . Unfortunately, Gearbox CEO Randy Pitchford almost immediately laid those theories to rest, stating that the image shown in the trailer was not Handsome Jack but "something far more dangerous and sinister."

Despite Borderlands 4 's presumed main antagonist not being Handsome Jack, the idea of it being far more dangerous and sinister than the iconic villain could be just what the series needs. The Borderlands franchise has now seen several main villains antagonizing its world and the Vault Hunters attempting to thwart their schemes, but the comedic antics of the most recent mainline installment's villains were highly controversial. As such, Borderlands 4 returning to a villain whose goals and personality might mirror and even improve upon Handsome Jack's sounds promising.

After Borderlands 3, Borderlands 4's Darker Villain Sounds Promising

Borderlands 3's Villains Weren't Serious or Threatening Enough

Borderlands 3 is by no means a bad game and its initial reviews say that much, but it might just be the most divisive of any mainline Borderlands game ever made. The Borderlands series has always been known for its over-the-top humor and exaggerated violence, so that's to be expected of a new installment. However, Borderlands 3 arguably takes things a bit too far in that regard, even to the point that its villains, the Calypso Twins, aren't threatening enough to be taken seriously. Their personalities, along with their goals, don't make them anywhere near the villain that Handsome Jack is — of course, it could be argued that any villains following Handsome Jack were doomed from the start.

In keeping with modern trends, as Borderlands has been known to do, the Calypso Twins are modeled after social media influencers like those that can be found on YouTube, Twitch, and Instagram. Their personalities are a bit overblown, to the point that their meme potential drastically outweighs the threat that they pose. They certainly have the charisma of Handsome Jack, as any decent social media influencer should, but they aren't quite dark or menacing enough to merit being simultaneously feared and respected, as Handsome Jack is. Finally, it quickly becomes painfully obvious in Borderlands 3 that the Calypso Twins are trying really hard to be another Handsome Jack, which only makes things worse.

However, Borderlands 4's "dangerous and sinister" villain might make up for the shortcomings of Borderlands 3 .

Borderlands 4's Dark Villain Might Make Up for Borderlands 3's Shortcomings

It's good news that Borderlands 4 's villain sounds like a much bigger threat than Handsome Jack, as that might play a major role in the game's success. What Borderlands 4 needs to ensure it doesn't do is try to recreate the second game's antagonist in some way. Regardless of how much the Borderlands community has come to love Handsome Jack over the years, there is no justification for attempting to clone his personality and goals as Borderlands 3 tried and failed to do. It is an endeavor that will likely always result in a failed outcome, so Borderlands 4 needs to avoid it at all costs.

According to what is shown in the Borderlands 4 teaser trailer, it could be that The Watcher is this installment's antagonist, who was originally revealed in 2014's Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel . At the very least, the teaser trailer has Eridian literally and figuratively written all over it, suggesting the alien race will play a significant role in Borderlands 4 . If that is the case, it could be a very dark entry indeed, taking players deeper into the backstory of the Borderlands franchise than they have ever been before.

item.title: Resident Evil Zero - Official Announce Trailer
item.description: Resident Evil Zero launched in 2002, telling the story of the STARS Bravo Team before the events of the first game in the series. It was also the first game featuring Billy Coen, who would later pop up in The Umbrella Chronicles.

item.title: Black Myth: Wukong— All Missables
item.description:
Quick Links

  • All Missables In Black Myth: Wukong
  • All Chapter 1 Missables In Black Myth: Wukong
  • All Chapter 2 Missables In Black Myth: Wukong
  • All Chapter 3 Missables In Black Myth: Wukong
  • All Chapter 4 Missables In Black Myth: Wukong
  • All Missables In Chapter 5 Of Black Myth: Wukong
  • Old Man's Quest

Black Myth: Wukong is a massive game that lets players experience a magnificent story from Chinese mythology. The game has six chapters in total, and each of them is filled with unique enemies. Players are advised to explore every corner, even though there is no open world.

The reason is that almost every area contains secrets that cannot be uncovered unless players look closely. In some cases, players will miss out on certain quests and items completely once they go beyond the point of no return. So, in this guide, players will learn how to find all the missables in Black Myth: Wukong.

All Missables In Black Myth: Wukong

Players can find all missables in Black Myth: Wukong listed below:

  • Wandering Wight Spirit
  • Second Rat Prince Spirit
  • Auspicious Lantern
  • Apramana Bat Spirit
  • Venomous Armguard
  • The Scorpionlord Boss Fight
  • Daoist Mi Boss Fight
  • Purple Talisman Quest
  • Horse Guai Quest
  • Old Man's Quest

All Chapter 1 Missables In Black Myth: Wukong

The first chapter of Black Myth: Wukong only has one missable : the Wandering Wight boss fight. If players somehow manage to access the secret area of Chapter 1 and beat the Elder Jinchi, they will not be able to fight the Wandering Wight . Players can find this enemy just beyond the Outside the Forest Keeper's Shrine.

All Chapter 2 Missables In Black Myth: Wukong

Like the previous chapter, Chapter 2 also has a single missable , and it is also a Spirit. When players face the King of the Flowing Sands and the Second Rat Prince , it is important to kill the King first . If players take down the Second Prince before dealing with the King, they will miss out on the former's spirit .

All Chapter 3 Missables In Black Myth: Wukong

When players are taken to the Pagoda Realm, they will notice big enemies with lanterns for heads. There are nine of them in total, and they must all be killed before players face Captain Wise-Voice . If they beat Captain Wise-Voice, they will lock themselves out of getting the Auspicious Lantern , a rare Curio.

The Lantern Wardens only appear when the Destined One enters a daze.

The second missable is the Apramāṇa Bat Spirit. This is an enemy that is found just beyond the North Shore of the Bitter Lake Keeper's Shrine. Players need to stick to the right side of the coastline, and they will eventually reach an area with a massive snake skeleton. Walk a few paces to trigger a cutscene. Once it is over, fight the Apramana bat to claim its Spirit. This must be done before beating Yellowbrow.

All Chapter 4 Missables In Black Myth: Wukong

The first missable in Chapter 4 is the Venomous Armguard . To obtain this piece of armor, players must break all of Venom Daoist's extra arms in the first encounter. It is highly recommended to use the weakest weapon, as it will allow players to bust all the arms.

If players fail to break all appendages coming out of Venom Daoist's back, they will need to retry in New Game+ as there is a trophy linked to it.

The other missables are found on Purple Cloud Mountain, which is the secret area of Chapter 4. To access this place, players need to beat the Venom Daoist twice. Upon defeating the Venom Daoist for the second time, players need to interact with the wall behind them to enter the Purple Cloud Mountain.

Daoist Mi Quest

Daoist Mi can be found near the Petalfall Hamlet Keeper's Shrine . Players need to talk to him, after which they need to go looking for the Violet Hail. This item can be acquired by defeating the yellow-robed enemies nearby. Upon securing the item, talk to Daoist Mi. Wait for the cutscene to finish, then beat Daoist Mi to earn the Violet Hail (Spell) transformation.

The Scorpionlord And The Stained Jade Gourd

This boss can be found sitting on the roof of a hut near the Bounds of Deity’s Abode . Go up the stairs and break the jars to start the boss fight. This enemy is extremely strong, and players will need to be on their toes to beat him. After defeating him, players will gain the Stained Jade Gourd .

Players must not go to face the Duskveil before fighting the Scorpionlord ; otherwise, they will miss out on the journal entry and the gourd.

The final missable is the Crane Immortal's journal entry for which players need to complete the Purple Talismans quest.

Players can consult this guide for a detailed account of the Purple Talismans quest.

All Missables In Chapter 5 Of Black Myth: Wukong

The penultimate missable in Black Myth: Wukong is related to the Horse Guai's quest . Players will encounter him in every chapter, except for the final one. Players must make a note of talking to Horse Guai in every chapter before beating the final boss. If they proceed without talking to him, they will be locked out of the quest. The Horse Guai can be found in the following locations:

  • Found inside a cave near the Back Hills Keeper's Shrine
  • Found under a gazebo near the Earth Wolf's arena
  • Found inside a building close to the Temple Entrance Keeper's Shrine
  • Found trapped inside a cocoon on the way to the Cliff of Oblivion Keeper's Shrine
  • Found inside a cart that is just beyond the Valley Entrance Keeper's Shrine.

After completing Chapter 5, go back to his last location and interact with the cart to complete the quest.

Exhaust all the dialogue of Horse Guai every time you meet him to complete the quest.

Old Man's Quest

This is the final missable in Black Myth: Wukong. Players have to talk to the bearded old man in every chapter and exhaust the dialogue. If they don't, they will have to retry in New Game+.

item.title: Space Marine 2 Has Been Review Bombed
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 has endured a small review-bombing campaign on Steam following its early access launch.
  • Some Steam users have taken issues with the fact that the game stealth-installs Epic Online Services and has a rather comprehensive EULA requiring players to agree to personally identifiable data collection.
  • Although Space Marine 2 hence debuted with a "Mixed" user review label on Steam, its ratings have already improved to "Mostly Positive" by September 7.

Warhammer 40k: Space Marine 2 has been the subject of a review-bombing campaign on Steam. While the effort initially managed to mess with the game's overall user rating on Valve's storefront, Warhammer 40k: Space Marine 2 has already largely recovered from it.

The sequel to Relic Entertainment's 2011 third-person shooter is officially scheduled to hit the market on Monday, September 9. However, anyone who has pre-ordered one of the higher-tier editions of Warhammer 40k: Space Marine 2 has been able to jump into the game since September 5.

Space Marine 2 Review-Bombed Over Epic Online Services and Privacy Concerns

And while Space Marine 2 was met with largely positive reviews from critics, its initial audience reception has been somewhat more polarizing. That's reflected in the fact that the game debuted with "Mixed" user ratings on Steam, as hundreds of early adopters decided to review it negatively on Valve's storefront due to its reliance on Epic Online Services and a rather exhaustive end-user license agreement (EULA) that raised some privacy concerns. On the subject of the former, some players have taken issue with the fact that Space Marine 2 installs Epic Online Services without informing them about it. The framework itself is used by the shooter for offering cross-platform multiplayer.

Game Rant's review of Space Marine 2 's EULA suggests it is comparable to those attached to most other contemporary Saber Interactive titles, including Teardown , SnowRunner , and Expeditions: A MudRunner Game . While all of these mandate players to agree to some degree of personal data collection by publisher Focus Entertainment, none of their clauses are anything out of the ordinary compared to what the average multiplayer game requires these days. The information that players agree to have collected comprises their demographic data and in-game statistics.

Space Marine 2 Steam Reviews Improved Following Early Access Launch

The shooter's overall Steam rating improved to "Mostly Positive" as of September 7. The game currently sits at a 76% player recommendation rate on the platform, meaning it's just four percentage points short of attaining the "Positive" review label. Looking at the contents of its latest negative user reviews, the backlash against the game's EULA and stealth installation of Epic Online Services has largely died down, with most of the current player criticism being directed at some newly discovered Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 bugs.

Meanwhile, the game's critical reception has been nothing short of stellar. This is reflected in its "Strong" OpenCritic rating, derived from an 89% reviewer recommendation rate and an aggregate score of 83.

item.title: Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom Marks the Return of One Character After a 20-Year Absence
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • The Business Scrub returns in Echoes of Wisdom after a 20-year absence, now running smoothie shops.
  • The character's role has evolved over the years in the Zelda series, offering wares at higher costs.
  • Echoes of Wisdom's Business Scrub sells smoothies, which align with Breath of the Wild's cooking system.

Despite starring a protagonist who has never filled that role in a mainline Zelda installment, T he Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom looks more and more like a classic Zelda game with every reveal, wearing its franchise connections on its sleeve with recurring characters, themes, and resources. One such recurring character who hasn't been seen in the franchise for two decades is now returning in Echoes of Wisdom to provide Zelda with some valuable items.

The Business Scrub is a recurring side character in the Legend of Zelda series, offering players important, albeit expensive, items they may need on their adventure. In Echoes of Wisdom , however, the Business Scrub runs the game's smoothie shops in its most distinguished role in nearly 26 years.

The Business Scrub Returns in Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom

Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom's Business Scrub Hasn't Been Around Since Zelda: The Minish Cap

Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom 's Business Scrub hasn't been seen in the series for twenty years, which means the most recent Zelda installment it appeared in was T he Minish Cap . Its debut was in Ocarina of Time , in which it appeared in vast numbers compared to other installments. After that, it appeared in Majora's Mask , though less in number than before, then once again in Oracle of Seasons and Oracle of Ages . It's not the most prominent character in the franchise, but thanks to Ocarina of Time 's massive success and wide recognition as the best Zelda game ever made, the Business Scrub holds a special place in The Legend of Zelda .

Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom's Business Scrub Runs Hyrule's Smoothie Shops

Despite being a recurring side character in The Legend of Zelda , the Business Scrub hasn't always functioned the same way. On the one hand, it always plays a vendor role, offering Link various wares in exchange for rupees. However, the Business Scrub has often only been accessed by first pacifying it in battle. Beginning with its Ocarina of Time debut, the Business Scrub would fire a Deku Nut at Link, which would then need to be deflected back at the Business Scrub. Once the Business Scrub was pacified, players could speak with the character to receive an exclusive deal on valuable merchandise.

Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom 's Business Scrub hasn't been seen in the series for twenty years, which means the most recent Zelda installment it appeared in was T he Minish Cap .

This trend continued in Majora's Mask , but changed with the release of Oracle of Seasons and Oracle of Ages , where dealings with Business Scrubs were a bit more casual compared to previous iterations. Specifically, whereas Ocarina of Time and Majora's Mask required players to defeat the Business Scrub before they were allowed to purchase wares from it, Oracle of Seasons and Oracle of Ages removed that requirement entirely, letting players interact with them as they would a normal vendor immediately upon encountering them.

While The Minish Cap once again required players to pacify the Business Scrubs before interacting with them, from the look of things, Echoes of Wisdom 's version of the character seems to take things back to the days of Oracle of Seasons and Oracle of Ages when Business Scrubs were strictly business. It appears Business Scrubs are truly only there to sell smoothies to Zelda in Echoes of Wisdom without needing to be pacified beforehand, though that's only according to what has been revealed so far.

The change would be a welcome one anyway, since smoothie shops in Echoes of Wisdom are such a central part of its gameplay.

Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom is certainly not short on recurring characters and themes, just like any other game in the franchise. Even so, it's great to see the Business Scrub back in action, and this time, selling something it has never sold before that capitalizes on the success of Breath of the Wild and Tears of the Kingdom 's cooking system.
